data.text: Contents
Appendix 2: Mouth care for patients who are at risk or have developed mouth problems who are not able to perform mouth care independently ..................................................... 15

Appendix 3: Mouth care of highly dependent and/or unconscious patient ......................... 17 Appendix 4: Mouth care of patients with dysphagia ........................................................... 19 Appendix 5: Mouth Care Observation Chart ...................................................................... 22 Appendix 6: Mouth care for fasting patients ....................................................................... 23 Appendix 7: Medications and symptom control in mouth care ........................................... 24 Appendix 8: Mouth care for Patients receiving Chemotherapy .......................................... 25 Appendix 9: Mouth care for patient having radiotherapy to head and neck ....................... 26 Appendix 10: Head and Neck cancer patients – prescriber's protocol ............................... 28 Appendix 11: Template risk assessment for the use of foam swabs in Critical Care ......... 29
Introduction

Oral health is defined as “A standard of health of the oral and related tissues which enables an individual to eat, speak and socialise without active disease or embarrassment and which contributes to general wellbeing” (Department of Health, 1994)
It is of primary importance to ensure the patient's comfort whilst facilitating their ability to eat and drink.
These multi-disciplinary guidelines include direction for mouth care as follows:
Mouth care for patients at risk or who have developed mouth problems
Mouth care of patients with dysphagia
Mouth care for highly dependent and dying patients.
Mouth care for fasting patients.
Mouth care for patients receiving chemotherapy.
Mouth care for patients having head and neck radiotherapy.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to provide guidance on the management of oral hygiene in various patient groups that ensures patients are safely cared for to the level of best practice.
To provide clear instruction and guidance:
On the assessment and monitoring mouth status
Performing mouth care in various patient groups
Evaluating outcomes of mouth care
Provision of patient and carer education
Definitions

table_items.text: Mouth care is defined as the scientific care of mouth and teeth (Thomas 1997)
Candidiasis or thrush is a fungal infection (mycosis) of any species from the genus Candida (one genus of yeasts). Candida albicans is the most common agent of Candidiasis in humans.

Aphthous stomatitis is a common cause of benign and non- contagious mouth ulcers, (also called canker sores or aphthae). This condition is characterized by the repeated formation of ulcers in the mouth, in otherwise healthy individuals. These ulcers occur periodically and heal completely between attacks. Symptoms range
from a minor nuisance to interfering with eating and drinking, and more severe forms may be debilitating.
Abbreviation meaning "when necessary" (from the Latin "pro re nata", for an occasion that has arisen, as circumstances require, as needed).

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
All Site Clinical Directorate Governance Groups Responsible for:
Reviewing and undertaking actions in relation to the implementation and on- going review of processes detailed in this guideline.
Ensuring relevant training and competencies for relevant staff is up to date.
Reviewing  and  undertaking  actions  related  to  any  incident  within  the directorate in relation to this guideline.
Ensuring  that  safe  systems,  practices  and  training  programmes  are  in implemented  within  directorate  inpatient  areas  where  mouth  care  is
practised.
Matrons Responsible for:
Supporting  the  dissemination  and  implementation  of  this  guideline  and procedural documents within areas of their responsibility.
Ensuring that guidelines and procedures are followed at all times within their area of responsibility.
Supporting audit, governance and monitoring programme and ensure any follow up and action plans are developed and actioned in an appropriate and timely manner.
Ward/Department Managers Responsible for:
All duties listed under ‘Registered Nurses' they personally perform.
Supporting the dissemination and implementation of this guidelines and procedural documents.
Ensuring that guidelines and procedures are followed at all times.
Ensuring all staff working with the clinical area has the appropriate and up- to-date  training  and  competencies  required  and  maintain  their  personal records to this effect.
Ensuring the reporting of any risks or incidents in relation mouth care.
Registered Nurse Responsible for:
Familiarising  themselves  with  this  guideline  and  implementation  of  all procedural documents as part of their normal duties and responsibilities.
Attending training and update as required, maintaining their professional documentation record.
Ordering supplies of required and maintain stock control to ensure access to medicines and equipment for mouth care.
Providing  supervision  of  nursing  students  and  health  care  assistants undertaking mouth care.
Being  aware  of  and  monitoring  the  patient  for  side  effects  and  acting appropriately.
Appropriately documenting provision of mouth care and medications on the appropriate tool and inpatient drug chart, in accordance with the Policy for Administration of Medicines (MMP003).
Health Care Assistants Responsible for:
Familiarising  themselves  with  this  guidelines  and  implementation  of  all procedural documents as part of their normal duties and responsibilities.
Attending training and update as required, maintaining their professional documentation record.
Providing mouth care as outlined in this guideline.

4.5.1  All hospital clinical staff require the knowledge of the importance of mouth care and good oral health and the links to general health and well-being. They also require the skills gained through training on how to carry out mouth care and assessment of the mouth, and the ability to use the tools needed to provide good mouth care.
Inclusion criteria
The provision of mouth assessment, care planning, and education of appropriate medicines / products must be undertaken by a registered nurse as per standards set out in the NMC Code.

The  provision  of  mouth  care  can  be  undertaken  by  Health  Care  Assistants. Assessment of competency of Health Care Assistant must be completed by the registered nurse. This is in line with competencies, records of which should be held in their personal file.
General principles
Patients most at risk of developing oral problems are those who become unable to maintain good oral hygiene themselves. Predisposing factors to poor oral health are:
Mouth breathing
Oxygen therapy
Anorexia, poor nutritional status/reduced fluid intake/fasting.
Nausea and vomiting
All advanced disease/debilitation.
Chemotherapy (immuno-suppressants and immunocompromised patients)
Radiotherapy (increased in local treatment of head and neck)
Drugs: (Opiates, Steroids, Antibiotics, Diuretics)
Local tumours.
Reduced saliva production
Lack of knowledge, motivation, poor mental/physical health preventing the patient maintaining their own oral hygiene.
Palliative patients
Patients with dementia
Frail elderly patients
Learning disabilities
Delirium
Stroke
Ventilated patients
Medicines that can alter the flora and fauna of the oral cavity by reducing protective salivary secretion include:
Anticholinergic
Antiemetic
Antibiotics
Diuretics
Antihypertensive
Anticonvulsants
Antidepressants/ Anxiolytic
Antispasmodics
Analgesics – particularly opiates
Antidiarrheal
Antihistamine
Antipsychotic
Bronchodilators
Cardiovascular
Decongestants
Antiparkinsonian
Muscle relaxant
Proton Pump Inhibitors
Diuretics
Sedatives
Medicines that suppress the immune system include the following:
Steroid therapy
Chemotherapy /Cytotoxic drugs
Training requirements

Preventative measures may help promote comfort and reduce risk of developing mouth problems. However, patients who have advanced disease are at risk of developing subsequent problems. There is evidence that hospitalisation is
associated with deterioration in oral health of patients (Terezakis et al, 2011). This is linked to:
An increase in hospital acquired infections
Poor nutritional intake
Longer hospital stays
Increased care costs

Preventative measure should involve high a quality oral status assessment in order to detect and anticipate problems at an early stage, to highlight patients who need support with mouth care, and to enhance effective management of mouth problems, whilst complying with the Essence of Care 2010. Recording mouth care is an essential part of general care. If it is not recorded, it can be assumed that it is not being done. Tooth-brushing can be the most effective way of removing debris and should be used if the patient can tolerate it. In addition, it is essential that the patient is educated about the importance of tooth-brushing as evidence supports effectiveness in the removal of debris. It is the action of removing debris regularly (tooth brushing / rinsing), that maintains a healthy mucosa rather than the agents used.
Teaching patients and their families
It is of vital importance to include patients and their families in mouth care needs and care plan. This will enable an understanding of the principles and their participation in practice.
Assessment observation and evaluation

Continuous assessment, observation and evaluation of the patient's oral status should ensure effective practice and alleviation of mouth problems. This management forms a model of care from admission to discharge, or death. This is the responsibility of the registered nurse, but multidisciplinary input from the healthcare assistants is of paramount importance, and is to be utilised in conjunction with on-going supervised care. Knowledge of the ‘normal mouth' and ability to recognise deviations from this is essential, requiring feedback and communication to the registered nurse and the medical team.

Eight essential “Healthy Features” (appendix 1) outline the methods the registered nurse utilises to fully assess mouth status. Full documentation of mouth assessment status must be included in the nursing assessment, using the oral score and tool. The tool incorporates specific considerations i.e.: chemotherapy. Assessment frequency will depend on the following scores:
0 – 8 weekly assessment   every 48 hours
10 and above every 24 hours
Access to stock for management of mouth care
All wards and departments must be stocked sufficiently with the following equipment:
Oral score assessment tool
Mouth care observation chart
Soft toothbrushes
Toothpastes
Pen torches
Tongue depressors
Mouth care products including Moutheze swabs with white and yellow handles, plastic tumbler, gauze, Oral balance gel (Biotene)
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Oncology Governance Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Oncology guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Oncology Governance Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 11)

Appendix 1: Assessment and care planning
Eight essential healthy features
Guidelines for assessment and provision of mouth care in adults / MSEGL-21008/ 1.1
Page  of
Feature
VOICE Normal for the patient
(no pain or difficulty swallowing)
SWALLOW Normal, comfortable
swallow
LIPS Smooth pink and moist
TONGUE Pink, moist and papillae
present
SALIVA watery
MUCOUS MEMBRANES Pink and
moist
TEETH AND DENTURES
Clean and no debris (or denture area)  GINGIVA Pink and firm
Method of assessment
Auditory – converse with patient
Observe. Ask patient to swallow.  Visual observation. Feel lip texture   Visual observation. Feel tongue
Tongue depression. Touching centre of  tongue and the floor of the mouth
Visual observation of membranes  Visual – use tongue depressor
Visual  observation  of  teeth  or  denture  bearing area.

table_items.text: The registered nurse must carry out assessment and care planning. Assess and record the oral status of the patient's mouth using the oral assessment tool.
To have documented baseline assessment of oral status.
Formulate and document nursing care plan in conjunction with the patient and /or carer. Including specific instructions regarding frequency of mouth care and agents to be used.
To have prescribed nursing care plan for all members of participating nursing team.
Teach and explain mouth care regime and techniques to patient and carer Provide leaflet regarding mouth care.
To support compliance and patients ability to manage care.
Record and document all care and actions taken in patients care records and on oral assessment tool.

data.text: Oral Assessment tool

table_items.text: Coated or loss of papillae or dry
Yes – intense regimen ( head and Neck, Leuks/ Teratomas)
Not able to perform own mouth care

data.text: Appendix 2: Mouth care for patients who are at risk or have developed mouth problems who are not able to perform mouth care independently
The following steps may be performed by patient and/carer after full instructions/supervision by registered nurse. This should be documented in the patient's clinical record.
Equipment
The following may be left with the patient, if appropriate, and renewed daily.
Prescribed mouth care (kept in locker)
Small toothbrush and toothpaste and if prescribed, Chlorhexidine mouthwash
Moutheze swab – for 12hrly use, white handle for daytime and yellow handle for night- time
0.9% Sodium chloride 25ml sachet for patients on chemotherapy
Disposable kidney dish/bowl
Paper tissues
Tap water and plastic disposable tumbler (Fresh each procedure)
Gloves (non latex)
Denture container (as necessary)
Wooden spatula
Small torch
Oral balance gel (Biotene)

table_items.text: Explain the procedure to the patient and/or carer and obtain consent.
Ensure the patient is in a comfortable position appropriate for the procedure.
The procedure can be carried out with minimum discomfort.
Wash and dry hands, put on gloves
To protect the nurse and minimise the risk of infection
Examine the patient's mouth using a tongue depressor and pen torch. Remove the patient's dentures if applicable and place in a denture pot with clean water.
To enable assessment prior to seizure.
Apply oral balance Gel (Biotene) to the lips.
To prevent trauma to the lips.
Dentate patients: Brush the teeth, gums and tongue using the tooth brush and toothpaste/OR water/Chlorhexidine mouthwash and Moutheze swab.
To remove adherent materials from the teeth, tongue and gum surfaces. Brushing stimulates gingival surfaces to maintain tone and prevent circulatory stasis.
Moutheze swabs may be used for cleaning oral mucosa. Comply with MDA-2008-017.
To effective remove plaque and debris.

Assist the patient to rinse out their mouth using a mouthwash or water. Ensure paper tissues are to hand. If the patient is unable to rinse their mouth independently, use a clean toothbrush to clean the teeth and Moutheze swab to wipe the gums and oral mucosa (a gloved swabbed finger can also be used).
To remove loosened debris and toothpaste and freshen the mouth. To remove loosened debris and toothpaste and freshen the mouth.
Apply oral balance gel (Biotene) to the teeth and the mouth if appropriate.
To provide comfort and promote moisture.
Apply oral balance gel (Biotene) to the lips.
Cracked dry lips are a risk for infection and affect speech ability. Moisturising them maintains integrity and function.
Clean the patient's dentures with toothbrush and soak in denture solution for 30 minutes. Rinse and brush with water and return to the patient.
Where appropriate administer prescribed mouth care solutions after cleansing. Ask the patient to refrain from eating and drinking for 20 minutes after administration.
To ensure effective administration and action of medication.
Frequency of prescribed mouth care: 6-12 hourly basis as prescribed. Frequency of water mouth care: 2 hourly mouth care using water
To ensure effective mouth care and promote hygiene.
Dispose of non-reusable equipment as per policy
To reduce risk of cross infection.

Moutheze can be reused for up to 12hrs, white handle for daytime and yellow handle for night- time. Rinse under running cold water and leave upright in plastic disposable tumbler to air dry. Discard after 12hrs.
Wash and dry hands as per policy
To reduce risk of cross infection.
Evaluate care, update assessment if necessary and document in the clinical record. Record on mouth care observation chart (see appendix 6).
To ensure continuity of care and management. Measure outcome and evidence mouth care given.
Where appropriate the patient should be encouraged to drink as much fluid as possible. Encourage water or non-acidic drinks.
Oral tissues are more likely to remain healthy if they can be kept moist.

data.text: Appendix  3:  Mouth  care  of  highly  dependent  and/or  unconscious patient
Equipment
Tap Water (fresh each procedure)
Toothbrush or Moutheze swab – for 12hrly use, white handle for daytime and yellow handle for night-time
Toothpaste or Chlorhexidine mouthwash
Disposable plastic tumbler
Kidney bowl
Gloves (non latex)
Suction equipment available
Paper Tissues
Wooden spatula
Pen torch
Denture container as necessary
(Chlorhexidine mouthwash or gel can be used with a swabbed gloved finger if patient cannot comply with tolerating a toothbrush / paste).

table_items.text: Explain the procedure to the patient.
Unconscious patients may retain their ability to hear.
Place the patient in the lateral position with the head turned well towards the attended side.
Allow secretions to drain from the mouth instead of collecting at the back of the pharynx.
Wash and dry hands and apply gloves, as per policy.
Place towel under patient's face and over the upper shoulder and vomit bowl beside the patient's mouth. Clean and rinse patient's mouth as identified in the Appendix 3 steps 6-14.
Prevent soiling of bed linen patient's bed attire and maintain dignity.
Patients who are terminally ill use neutral liquids to their taste as appropriate.
May help with taste and first symptoms. Provides more familiar and pleasant taste. Intention to promote saliva.

Carers must not use suction. Nursing staff are required to use only if necessary. Gently suction the patient's mouth to remove secretions that have accumulated during the cleansing and rinsing. Suction should only be applied when the suction catheter tip is adjacent to the pooled secretions.
Prevent damage to mucosa. Prevent collection of secretions and fluid in the posterior pharynx.
Apply oral Balance gel (Biotene) to mouth and/or to the lips.
Cracked dry lips are a risk for infection and affect speech ability. Moisturising lips helps to maintain integrity and function.
Explain to the patient that the procedure is completed.
Remove gloves and reposition patient as appropriate.
Dispose of the non-reusable equipment and used linen.

Moutheze can be reused for up to 12hrs, white handle for daytime and yellow handle for night-time. Rinse under running cold water and leave upright in plastic disposable tumbler to air dry. Discard after 12hrs.
Wash hands and dry as per policy.
Evaluate care and document in the clinical record. Record on mouth care observation chart (see appendix 6).
To ensure continuity of care and management. Measure outcome and evidence mouth care given.

data.text: Appendix 4: Mouth care of patients with dysphagia

Dysphagia is a medical term for swallowing difficulties. Patients with dysphagia are at increased risk of poor oral health and aspiration of unclean secretions (Ortega et al 2014). Poor oral hygiene is linked to increased rates of aspiration pneumonia in this population (Langmore et al 1998). Regular and thorough mouth care is associated with reduced rates of pneumonia (Yoneyama et al 2002).

Tooth-brushing  should  be  completed  at  least  twice  a  day.  However,  patients  with dysphagia are more likely to have food debris in the mouth after eating and their oral hygiene  should  be  inspected  after  every  meal  and  mouth  care  given  if  needed.  For patients who are nil by mouth, it is recommended to provide mouth care every 1-2 hours to manage dry mouth symptoms. For patients with a dry mouth, dry mouth gel should be applied four times daily.
Particular consideration must be taken when giving oral care to patients with dysphagia in order to prevent aspiration of toothpaste or oral debris.
Equipment
Tap Water (fresh each procedure)
Small, soft-headed toothbrush
Toothpaste (consider a non-foaming/SLS-free brand for dysphagic patients)
Dry mouth gel
Moutheze swab – for 12hrly use, white handle for daytime and yellow handle for night-time
Disposable plastic tumbler
Kidney bowl
Gloves (non-latex)
Suction equipment if necessary and available
Paper Tissues
Pen torch
Denture container as necessary
Chlorhexidine mouth wash or gel (if prescribed)

table_items.text: Explain to the patient that you will be giving mouth care.
Unconscious patients may retain their ability to hear.
Place the patient in an upright position with the head turned well towards the attended side.
Allow secretions to collect in the front of the mouth, instead of collecting at the back of the pharynx.
Wash and dry hands and apply gloves, as per policy.
Place towel under patient's face and over the upper shoulder and kidney bowl
Prevent soiling of bed linen and patient's bed attire, and to maintain dignity.
Examine the patient's mouth and tongue using a tongue depressor (if appropriate) and pen torch. Remove the patient's dentures if applicable and place in a denture pot with clean water.
To assess the patient's oral hygiene status and prepare the mouth for oral care.
Use moutheze swabs to remove any food debris or secretions from the mouth, including the lips, teeth, gums, tongue and palate. This may be used for cleaning oral mucosa. Comply with MDA-2008- 017.
To effective remove plaque and debris.

Apply a pea-sized amount of non-foaming toothpaste to a toothbrush and press into the bristles. - Dip the toothbrush in water to moisten. - Gently brush the teeth, gums, tongue and palate using the tooth brush. - Use moutheze and/or gauze to remove any residual toothpaste and secretions from the mouth. Patients with dentures: Remove dentures and place in a bowl. Using toothbrush and toothpaste clean the dentures and rinse with water. Soak in denture solution for 30 minutes. Rinse and return to the patient's mouth. Dentures should be removed overnight and replaced in the morning.

To remove adherent materials and bacteria from the teeth, tongue, palate and gum surfaces. Brushing stimulates gingival surfaces to maintain tone and prevent circulatory stasis. Patients with dysphagia may not have adequate oral control and therefore foaming toothpaste may be aspirated. To remove accumulated debris that can get build between denture plate and gums. For patients who may be NBM dentures can rub causing mouth sores. Nocturnal denture wearing is associated with increased risk of aspiration pneumonia.

If excess secretions remain in the mouth that cannot be removed, then consider oral suctioning. Carers must not use suction. Nursing staff are required to use only if necessary. Gently suction the patient's mouth (no more than 20 kPa) to remove excess secretions. Suction should only be applied when the suction catheter tip is adjacent to the pooled secretions.
Prevent damage to mucosa. Prevent collection of secretions and fluid in the posterior pharynx. Excess secretions can be aspirated, and if they are infected with bacteria this can cause pneumonia.
If the patient is prescribed chlorhexidine mouth wash, consider application of the gel alternative.
Patients with dysphagia may be unable to swill and spit mouthwash safely. Chlorhexidine gel reduces aspiration risk.
For patients with oral candida apply ‘nystatin' on the patients tongue. Carefully drip 1ml onto front of tongue whilst head
Nystatin needs to be applied topically onto the tongue but in small amounts so that it can be absorbed sublingually and not
Once clean, apply dry mouth gel (e.g. Biotene) to the lips and mouth with a gloved finger or foam swab.

Cracked dry lips are a risk for infection and affect speech ability. Moisturising them maintains integrity and function. To promote moisture and comfort for NBM patients and prevent accumulation of dried secretions.
Explain to the patient that the procedure is completed.
Remove gloves and reposition patient as appropriate
Dispose of the non-reusable equipment and used linen.

Moutheze can be reused for up to 12hrs, white handle for daytime and yellow handle for night-time. Rinse under running cold water and leave upright in plastic disposable tumbler to air dry. Discard after 12hrs.
Wash hands and dry as per policy.
Evaluate care and document in the clinical record. Record on mouth care observation chart (see appendix 6).
To ensure continuity of care and management. Measure outcome and evidence mouth care given.

data.text: Page  of
Appendix 6: Mouth care for fasting patients
Mouth care for fasting patients should be consistent with those principles defined within this guideline and the guidelines for the pre-operative fasting for adults.

The following guidance is aimed at patients where only the predisposing factor is fasting. Any other factors present, the patient must receive mouth care interventions as previously outlined in this guideline.

table_items.text: Teach and discuss with patient how to attend to their mouth care and provide patient leaflet.
To promote understanding and patient's cooperation.
Instruct the patient how to brush and clean teeth/dentures/gums 12 hourly ensuring emphasis on rinsing the mouth after this without swallowing any water
To maximise the efficiency of cleaning teeth and minimise risk of microbial contamination.

Where prescribed instruct the patient how to use the antiseptic mouthwash (Chlorhexidine/Oraldene) as prescribed. Ensure the patient is aware not to swallow mouthwash. The solution may be patient's usual mouthwash agent. No more frequently than 6 hourly.
To ensure safe use of mouthwash and promote comfort.
Instruct the patient to rinse mouth with water at least 2 hourly whilst fasting.
To increase the patient's comfort and feeling of wellbeing. To clean and rinse the mouth.
Instruct the patient to apply oral balance gel (Biotene) to their lips.
Cracked, dry lips are a risk for infection and affect speech ability. Moisturising them maintains integrity and function.

data.text: Appendix 7: Medications and symptom control in mouth care
Contraindicated
The following agents are contraindicated in mouth care and should not be available at Mid and South Essex NHS Trusts:
Symptom control
Please refer to Essex Palliative Care formulary for symptom management guidelines for:
Appendix 8: Mouth care for Patients receiving Chemotherapy

Mucositis  is  a  common  side  effect  of  chemotherapy  with  incidence  rates  of  40%. Prevention and management are important issues as mucositis can cause pain, reduce oral intake, increase the patients' risk of infection, delay chemotherapy and result in dose reductions. The severity of mucositis depends on the chemotherapy agents used, the administration regimen as well as various patient related factors.
Dentate patients receiving intensive chemotherapy regimens should be referred for dental assessment prior to start of treatment. This should be 10 days prior to treatment.
To prevent a sore mouth associated with chemotherapy
Salt water mouthwash 10mls after meals and at bedtime (Inpatients to be prescribed 0.9% Saline 25ml sachets)
If the patient has gum disease or salt water mouthwash proves inadequate then Chlorhexidine /Oraldene mouthwash 10mls four times a day if required.

Patients on a ‘high risk' regime may require salt water mouthwash every 2 hours. These patients should have Chlorhexidine / Oraldene mouthwash prescribed as it is possible that salt water mouthwash alone may not be sufficient.
Mouth care for patients receiving chemotherapy should be consistent with the principles defined within this document.

table_items.text: Educate and explain to the patient/ or carer, their mouth care regime with specific reference to prescribed mouthwash regime.
To support patients understanding compliance and self-management.
Provide written information given to the patient.
Educate and explain to the patient how to clean teeth/dentures twice daily and discuss the importance of this.
To support compliance and self- management and promote healthy mouth.
Educate and explain the importance of regular self-observation and report to nurse or doctor if any of the following occur: Pain Bleeding Difficulty swallowing Ulcers
For patient to have early detection of associated problems.
Educate and explain to the patient the importance of informing dentists of current chemotherapy when receiving dental treatment.

data.text: Appendix 9: Mouth care for patient having radiotherapy to head and neck

Radiotherapy poses similar problems to chemotherapy in that it causes immuno- and myelo-suppression.   However,  local  treatment  to  the  head  and  neck  areas  causes mucositis, which is extremely painful. Good pain management is essential for the patient to  be  able  to tolerate mouthcare and  maintain nutrition (Faber 2000).   A dry mouth (xerostomia) also has a profound effect on oral health and function. A major predicting factor of xerostomia is the amount of salivary gland in the radiation field. (Edwards 2000). Hypo salivation may be a long-term problem and the psychological effect should not be overlooked. The mouth has a vital role to play in speech, appreciation of food, drink and the expression of intimate affection. There are four key components to good nursing management for head and neck cancer patients undergoing external beam radiation:
An evidence based protocol (Ganley 1996)
Careful assessment and evaluation (Eilers 1985)
Patient education (Rugg 1990)
Intensive emotional support (Faber 2000)
Pre-irradiation Assessment

Dentate patients should be referred for a dental assessment prior to commencement of any radiation treatment. Any dental procedures required should be performed at least 10 days prior to the start of the treatment to allow adequate healing to take place.
Patients should be referred for a dietetic assessment and be given advice, if necessary, on smoking cessation and alcohol consumption (Rugg et al 1990).
The qualified nurse should adhere to assessment and care planning.
The level of intervention and care must be planned and complemented as follows for patients having radiotherapy to head and neck.
Provide written information to support education.
Levels of Intervention for Patients having Radiotherapy to Head and Neck
Less than or equal to 8  Perform “basic mouth care” as described
below.
Greater than 8 up to and including 10  Performing “basic mouth care” applying
individual interventions if required, example anti fungals and analgesia.
Greater than 10  Perform “basic mouth care”. Apply
individual interventions for appropriate indications.
Basic mouth care (RT)
Basic mouth care should be started preferably before irradiation or at least on the first day of treatment.
Dentate patients
Patients with dentures
Advanced mouthcare (RT)
Medication and symptom management
Appendix 10: Head and Neck cancer patients – prescriber's protocol
The following protocols are for reference only and may not be administered without a prescription and should be prescribed as per medicines management policy.

table_items.text: Nystatin suspension 100,000 units per ml, use 5 ml as a mouth wash four times a day preferably after meals until the mucosa has healed post irradiation.
Severe Candidiasis or infection unresponsive to Nystatin mouthwash
Fluconazole 50-100 mgs (7-10 days daily with or without Amphotericin mouthwash until mucosa healed post irradiation).
Candidiasis of the pharynx or oesophagus
Fluconazole 50-100mgs daily until healed post irradiation.
Fluconazole 100 mgs daily until healed post irradiation.

Patients with a history of recurrent candidiasis or with other predisposing factors, for example; regular steroid administration or use of inhaled medication should be started on regular Fluconazole 50 mgs daily during irradiation and for 7 days post irradiation.
Add Chlorhexidine (1st line) or Oraldene (2nd line) mouthwash 10mls qds if required
In severe cases of multiple ulcers Tetracycline mouthwash 250 mgs qds for a maximum of 5 days.
Soluble Co-codamol( 8/500 or 30/500 as appropriate) – 2 tablets 4 times a day (maximum 24 hr dose)
Aspirin and Hydrocortisone (300mg/5mg) mucilage 10mls QDS (preferably prior to meal time).
Morphine Sulphate solution, 10 mgs every 4 hours increased as necessary to control pain.
Morphine solution can be converted to slow release morphine 12 hourly or Fentanyl patch (Durogesic) if required.
Caphasol oral rinse, as detailed under basic mouthcare, can be used to treat mucositis

Appendix 11: Template risk assessment for the use of foam swabs in Critical Care

Areas such as critical care may find Moutheze not effective for their patients and may want to continue using foam swabs. They will need to complete the below risk assessment, the use of foam swabs will be for critical care only and on the understanding all staff are trained in the safe use of foam swabs.
Risk assessment Pro Forma
Page  of

INTRODUCTION: The principles of a risk assessment are to determine how the Trust is likely to be affected by any hazard. This will necessitate working out how severe the impact (I) will be, and how likely (L) that outcome is to occur. I is multiplied by L to achieve the risk rating. This form should be completed with due regard to the descriptors that can be found in Guidance for Risk Rating. From the highlighted matrix, the potential outcome for the Trust of business disruption, complaint, loss of reputation; or the potential for injury to staff, patients and visitors should be determined for each hazard and its associated risks.

table_items.text: Use of foam swabs for oral hygiene management in Critical Care
Current Risk Rating Target Risk Rating
Description of Perceived risk/ Impact of Risk
Potential for foam head to become removed from stick causing a potential chocking hazard.
Previous altenative product faulty and removed from Trust. Need to find alternative product to ensure safe and effective mouthcare.
Trust has withdrawn pink mouth sticks and issued alternative moutheze sticks.These are rubber and non absorbant.

Have sourced alternative company who provide higher quality foam sticks.All staff trained to test security of foam attachment prior to use. Decreased risk of patient's clamping down on foam swab causing it to detach due to their decreased conscious level. Patients to be observed at all times during use sticks. Continue with teeth cleaning using toothbrushes
